workshop.name: In-class problem: bullet into block
workshop.intro: This will be our first attempt at working a problem in class in groups.  The problem has been designed to be quick to do, and straightforward to mark since you will be marking it.
workshop.instructauthors:
Objectives

  1. Students will write down knows and unknowns for a collision.

  2. Students will solve for unknowns using conservation of momentum.

As shown in the diagram, an 8.0 g bullet is shot into a 1.2 kg block of wood. The block of wood splits into two pieces, one 800 g and the other 400 g. The bullet is lodged in the smaller piece. Before the bullet hit it the block of wood was sitting stationary on a smooth tabletop. The bullet was going at 400 m/s to the right before it hit the block. After the bullet lodges in it the 400 g piece is moving to the right at 12 m/s. Use the axes defined in the diagram.

a) Define variables and in terms of your defined variables obtain an expression for the velocity of the 800 g piece of wood after the collision.

b) Find the numerical value of the x-component of the velocity of the 800 g piece of wood after the collision.
workshop.instructreviewers: You will assess several (probably two) submissions by other people.  Follow the marking  guide.  The marking guide should be detailed enough that you won't have to use much judgement.
workshop.conclusion: Thanks for participating in this activity.  Note that you will have received two marks.  One mark will be for your submission.  The other mark is for the quality of feedback you gave to the submissions you were asked to assess.  The grade for the quality of assessment is found by comparing your assessment with the assessments of others who marked the same submission.  If you all agree on the grade then you get a perfect mark for your assessment.

workshopform_accumulative_dimension.description:
They should have started by writing down the knowns and unknowns, defining symbols as they do so.  The symbols \(m_A \), \(m_B\), \(m_C \), and \(m_D \) are already defined in the diagram in the question, so hopefully they used those.  If they didn't that could reduce the clarity of their solution but it is OK as long as they defined their symbols.  What they shouldn't have done is just use one symbol (like m), for the inertias of all of the objects.  They need a different symbol for each inertia.  If they just used the symbols defined in the diagram they don't need to have defined them.  They can just use them when they write their equation later.

Define different symbol for each inertia or just use symbols defined in the question diagram - 1 mark

Didn't clearly define symbols for inertia, or used the same symbol for multiple different inertias - 0 marks

They need to have defined symbols for the x-components of the velocities of the objects.  The symbols they use are not important as long as they have clearly defined them and used a different symbol for each velocity.  The symbols I would choose are:

vAx = 400 m/s

vBx = 0

vCx = ?

vDx = 12 m/s

Clearly defined symbols and all values (including identifying unknown) correct - 2 marks

Clearly defined symbols, but one or more values are mis-assigned - 1 mark

Did not  clearly define symbols, and/or used the same symbol (such as just "v") for multiple different velocities - 0 marks

Now they need to write down a conservation  of momentum equation.  Again, don't be picky about the symbols, as long as they stick with the symbols they defined earlier.  If they didn't clearly define symbols, but at this point write what appears to be a correct equation, then they should get part marks.

In terms of my symbols the equation would be

\( m_A v_{Ax} + m_B v_{Bx} = m_C v_{Cx} + m_D v_{Dx} \)

but  since \(v_{Bx} = 0 \) they might have gone straight to writing it down as

\( m_A v_{Ax} = m_C v_{Cx} + m_D v_{Dx} \)

which is absolutely fine.

Correct equation, written in terms of symbols defined earlier - 2 marks

Correct equation (or equation which appears correct  giving  benefit of doubt), but either consistent symbols were not used, or they had not defined their symbols earlier - 1 mark

No equation, or incorrect  equation, or choice of symbols is so unclear that you can't tell whether the equation is correct - 0 marks

They now need to (symbolically) solve for the unknown velocity component.  Note that the question explicitly asks for an expression for the unknown velocity.  So if they substitute in numbers before manipulating the equation they can't get this mark.

Manipulating  the equation I gave above I get

\( v_{Cx} = \frac{m_A v_{Ax} - m_D v_{Dx}}{m_C}\)

Equation correctly solved for vCx - 1 mark

Algebraic errors lead to wrong expression, or did not solve symbolically before putting in values - 0 marks

Now we can plug in the numbers and enter the expression into  our calculator.  They don't really need to have shown much for this process.  If they got the correct expression then they might have been comfortable enough to just enter it all into their calculator without writing  it down.  That's fine.  Also, it doesn't matter whether they worked in kg or g, as long as they were consistent working in one or the other.  Entering in the values, I get

\( v_{Cx} = \frac{(0.008 \, \textrm{kg})(400 \, \textrm{m/s}) - (0.408 \, \textrm{kg})(12 \, \textrm{m/s})}{0.8 kg} \)

= -2.12 m/s

Note that the negative sign is important!  It indicates that piece C "recoils" and moves in the opposite direction from the way the bullet was going.  This is counterintuitive, but does actually happen when bullets pass through objects.

Correct answer (including negative  sign) - 1 mark

Incorrect answer - 0 marks
